segments.text: One two, one two, one two, one two, one two.
One two.

This is October the 4th, and at Wednesday afternoon, sitting in the nice, quiet, cool living room, family room at 1502 Glade, getting ready to talk to Dr. Charles Bridges about his experiences, particularly as a faculty member here at Texas A&M.
To introduce yourself,
on tape and later in transcript, describe where you grew up, went to high school, then to college.
In other words, quickly get us to where you come here to be a faculty member.
I actually was a high school student at Webster, Texas, up through the ninth grade, and my father transferred to Jasper County in 1937.
and where I finished two years there at Jasper High School.
And that move was a little bit upsetting, as many would expect, and it took me two years before I could get at it.
One day a friend of mine came by and said, come go with us.
I said, where are you going?
He said, we're going to A&M.
I thought about that a while.
I said, when are you doing this and what are you going to do?
I decided I'd go with it.
He said, what are you going to take?
I said, what are you taking?
He said, veterinary medicine.
I said, okay.
Now what year was that?
That was 1941, September 1941.
and things just took their own life from that point because it was a challenge to take.
I'd always been interested in academia and I was interested in your experience as a Rice President.
When I was at Webster, my mentor there would program me to go to Rice.
My move then from there changed all that.
Let's slow down then.
If you got here in 41, that's too important.
Let's concentrate on your student years.
We might come back another day and do facts.
What did you know about Texas A&M before you got here?
I knew very little about Texas A&M.
At Jasper, there was not a lot of promotion of the colleges.
As a matter of fact,
The students really promoted business schools in Beaumont and things like that.
And a few of the classmates attended A&M because they were related.
For example, two of them were involved by working in veterinary clinics and things like that and had more of a
And I said, well, that might be all right.
Had you ever been over here to visit?
I'd never been here to visit.
And I had made an application when I got the county judge to give me a letter of recommendation, which is not unusual in small towns like that.
And I did not have a lot of family because they wanted me to stay around.
I was the only kid.
son.
And what did your family do for a living?

Well, my father worked for Harris County Probation Department for years until he went to Jasper and there he had built a home and he did the variety work, worked in carpentry and had his little farm, as a lot of people do, as kind of a supplement with working hours and things like this.
Describe, you came over with some friends in a car?
When we came to register, yes.
That was the only time.
What did you bring with you?
Describe all of the, or how little, whatever it was.
Well, I don't remember that I brought very much.
I remember that I came in and this individual was the same straight as I was.
He wasn't economically endowed and
He had been working the student labor, and he had a room with Mr. Myers out at the East Gate in the attic, and that's where I spent the first few times.
So then I went to, after that he introduced me to student employment.
I forget the name of it now, man and gentleman.
And so I went there, and he first gave me a job or two, I remember,
One day during the ball game, I was mowing Peggy Down's yard and somebody just kind of, without a real strong support, would do.
And then I later got a job with the housing office and Mr. Harry Boya and the commandant's office.
where I worked and actually I don't know whether I have a guard group now or not, but I was one of the participants in controlling that.
Do you remember what the pay was for those early jobs?
Well, there was many jobs.
I ran the newsstand at Sabeza.
At the same time,
worked and ran messages out of the guard room for students in the halls who kept their telephones down.
This was all the time you were a freshman?
Yeah.
Now, and where were you living?
I was in Ross Hall.
Describe your room.
What was in it and what furnishings and... We had a typical dorm room.
We had the bunk beds with the hard wooden chairs and
And that was a desk, it was a table mainly, and that was about it.
And of course there was a telephone there, and we answered the telephone, because what happened was the Operation Brian would call and say, would you go get so-and-so to get done with the telephone?
Because in those days, students would get adjusted to the telephone array in the dorms, they'd throw them off and tear them off the wall.
Was that the only telephone on your floor?
The telephone cordon, well the four involved the housing of the Commandant's office, and then our room, and I forget, the Commandant and the housing, Harry Boyer's office was the housing.
Boyer?
Describe how you got put into some outfit and how you and your fish buddies were treated in that outfit.
I would have to tell you that it was different not being living in the dorm.
I was an on-campus day student, you might say.
And I was assigned to A Troop, 1st Cavalry, and later, probably out of disgrace, pushed into Machine Gun Troop.
What, did it have a number, name?
No, it was just Machine Gun Troop and A Troop.
But you were in the Corps and wore a uniform, weren't you?
Oh, yes.
That's one reason I couldn't tell you how much I brought with me,
We were issued a certain number of trousers and shirts and what have you.
Otherwise, I participated.
Other than that, I didn't live in a dorm.
Describe your first fall.
Describe a typical day.
What times did you get up?
What did you do when?
Take from getting up all the way through that day.
I used to go to the 80 out and have a little trouble with some of this.

We would rise and clean straight up our rooms and take whatever's left there and then actually, as much as I was working multiple jobs, most of the time I would go and dust the Commandant's office because I'd swept it the night before.
And then come back and go eat at Sabisa and then back to the room and go to classes.
Did you fall in and march to Chao?
No.
But you ate in Sabisa.
Did you eat with an outfit?
No.
The best restaurant I remember, but I don't remember.
Okay.
All right.

Because most of the time, for example, I ate on the leg table, for example, in the evenings, and that was great because we would usually go to one of the athletes that had eaten and would have multiple pies and all the steaks we would eat.
And that first fall, do you remember the courses, some of the courses, some of the teachers you had that first fall?
English, math, science?
Yes, I remember some of the English, and that was tough.
I had always been a pretty good student, and yet not challenged very much.
Those were different times.
And as you know, the English department took no prisoners.
I don't remember that.
The math, I forget what it was, really.
I remember more about the biology and the old building over there.
Do you remember who the biology teacher was?
I can remember him now.
I can't put a name onto him.
I just offhand.
Were all the courses tough in terms of grades?
Those, actually, I did much like I did in high school.
I floated through because I had major problems and working schedule I had and not having the time for corrected glasses.

I would go to eat on the lake table, eat too much, get a quart of coffee to bring back to the room and take a nap and get up and drink that quart of coffee almost and then study 30 minutes and that was it.
The rest of it I got to class.
All right.
In the afternoons, did you have any spare time?
Or were you working just about all?
Well, it was working most of the time, yeah.
It was after they sent his classes over that it was to the janitor's job and most of that, and then back to the road and whatever came.
Did you make some close friends that first year?
Well, I had a lot of acquaintances, and yes, I kept so many of them that's gone by that I've continued to have relations with them.
I don't remember a lot of them I had.
There was not time for having fun, you might say.
Did you and the other fish get hazed?
Some, yes.
Describe.
Well, the hazing was usually, I have to say I was in a unique situation.
Being working for the commandant's office, I had a certain unasked for immunity.
So that made some difference, I think.
Did you and your buddies ever pull off any pranks or play tricks on anybody?
Oh, there was a little floating out of people, individuals, and stuff like that.
But, say, my life as a cadet was not the usual.
In other words, in a company, a troop, and what have you.
Two years old.
Older than anybody else.
As a matter of fact, I was of the age of the juniors and seniors.
And I guess my attitude may have reflected it.
And not intentionally, but... And that fall, there was a good football team here.
Did you go to all the games?
Very few of them, really.
How often did you go home?
About once a month.
How would you get there?
I would go out to Eastgate and stand in line with a thumb, and I would get a ride into Houston, and with a dime, I'd go across Houston.
I'd ride to get a ride to Beaumont, and with a dime, I'd get across Beaumont, and then I would hitchhike home.
And sometimes getting out late, I had to look for a ride, and we were there five miles out of town.
But it was, it was interesting.
Reckon how long it took to catch a ride from here to Jasper?
It was very, fairly fast considering.
I'm saying this, there was no time much spent except standing in line.
And of course sighted traffic was pretty good along that Highway 6.
Did you ever have any interesting experiences hitchhiking?
Well, occasionally.
I had a few girls try to pick me up in Houston and places like that, and of course I was headed home and there were other interests there.
But you never had any negative, no troubles, no problems?
No, not yet.
In other words, a young person, this is all new experience.
I did get into outside of Beaumont one time and had a ride with a trucker and I asked him where he was going.
He said, New Orleans.
I said, can I go?
So I ended up in New Orleans.
So far, I've not recorded a single negative Aggie hitchhiking experience.
No.
And you always wore your uniform hitchhiking?
Always.
There was no other way.
In those days, if you weren't in the service, at our age, there was a question about you.
And I think that young men, particularly in those days, were very conscious of that.
Now, did you and your buddies become part of the Aggie slang?
Did you all have the names for food?
Oh, yes, always.
What was your favorite Aggie chow food, chow hall food?
What was it?
Steak.
Chicken fried?
A lot of times it was just grilled.
Grilled?
Anything that you didn't like?
Yeah, ribs.
The ribs?
The ribs.
And was there always plenty of food?
Well, yes, always plenty of food.
No problem there.
Did your outfit get together and do anything as a group?
I can't remember that part.
What about December 7, 1941?
Do you remember that day?
Yes, I was at Ross Hall, and we heard all the gods on the radio.
Describe that as fully as you can.

Well, I can't remember that well, except it came about, and we were concerned, you know, it had all come before actually conscription had started to mean things, and we all had our numbers with the drafts.

and we're concerned about those things and I know that I remember when I went there and of course everybody had to get in the Corps or have a good excuse and I had to memorize the eye chart and I remember A-P-E-O-T-F-D-Z even this day I can remember that as being the critical line
that one of my cohorts has helped me memorize and so we were concerned about that and I think pretty well concerned about what was going to happen.
Of course, it turned out in the end that we were exempt as students of veterinary medicine and you may have known that and
Then later, we actually, after a couple years, we were actually given a commission on the basis of our education.
All right, now, but you were a freshman here that first year.
And you started off majoring in veterinary.
Did they call it pre-vet then?
They called it pre-vet.
Two years?
Oh, just one year.
Back to December 7, did you and your buddies listen to President Roosevelt when he talked to Congress that next day?
I don't remember that.
Do you remember any changes that happened in the routine after the war got going here?
Were you part of the group that went on the trimester?
Well, the trimester program, we went continuously, yes.
And did you go on into the vet school then?
Yes.
See, I was in vet school only three and a half years.
It was a five year program and we completed all that.
I was a class of 45 as I signed up.
And I graduated in February of 45.
As far as you can recall, what kind of grades did it take to get into vet school then?
Actually, as I remember it, you had to maintain a C average to make proper progress.
And if you didn't flunk out, you went off.
But the classes were restricted to 100.
And so when they adjusted for those that just didn't make it, then there was no selection committee, you could say, other than that.
Do you remember how many entered with you?
No, I don't.
And that would have been the fall of 1942?
No, it was, well, actually we knew nothing about entry of any of them.
to the veterinary school.
You signed up for the program in veterinary medicine.
Oh, and just went right on.
He just went through.
If you didn't flunk out, you made progress.
As I remember it, and the faculties of mine in here may have been such a thing.
Who was the dean then?
Marsteller was the dean, yeah.
Describe him, please, as you remember him.
Dr. Marsteller was an aging individual at that time, and
a very, well, old gentleman.
He was sad and wore, as I remember, a mustache.
And jovial at times and otherwise.
And the students, like they always do, always have opinions.
They say, well, he has good days or he has bad days.
And that was down in the administration building.
The old administration building on the second floor was where his offices were.
Now, where and where was the, and it was the School of Veterinary Medicine, wasn't it?
Yes.
And where was it located?
It occupied a good bit of Francis Hall, and a lot of the basic sciences were taught there, and then what is now, I think,
civil engineering building down on that northeast corner.
And where were the stalls and all for the animals?
The stalls were actually to the north of the, and actually adjacent to the civil engineering building.
Those buildings are basically there now.
They've been converted.
And then all of that area, this parking lot now was
was horse pasture.
And as I remember when I first came, University Drive was a gravel road, and you couldn't ride a bicycle very well on it because it was large river stones.
And as you remember your classmates in veterinary medicine, were most of them country boys or city boys?
I think it varied considerably, yeah.
I never knew a lot.

The only things I recognized, be it a country boy for example, would be the people from West Texas, which were ranchers and they actually were, set themselves apart because they were kind of cowboy types and what have you.
Did you make some close friends early on in veterinary medicine?
Who were some of those?
Well, I had a boy named Mike who was recently deceased.
What's his name?
Born in Myatt, M-Y-A-T-T. Of course, I came over here with Leland Grumbles, who is now retired and was head of microbiology.
Actually, I lived in the same community.
Charlie Boyd was in my class.
We were pretty close.
We never did room together.
Once you entered the vet school, did you remain in the Corps?
Oh, yes.
Well, we remained in the Corps until 43.
Okay.
And we completed all the basic ROTC.
And then they developed this

to, I think, some way or another, they got the, that the veterinary students, they were inactive, they had to conserve that because at that time they were, they had a heavy war over in India and China, and horse-drawn material, and the veterinarians were considered to be a kind of an important resource, according to that time.
Plus the fact that food services, the food inspection service,
that they, to form a way of giving them immunity from being called in, they were commissioned, second lieutenant in the medical administrative corps.
Now, as you began your veterinary studies, was there any ceremony?
to welcome you first-year students?
No.
You just started.
We were there.
You were there.
To whom did you and your friends turn for advice?
What courses to take?
What to do about this?
Who was there?
We turned to each other, and actually the curriculum was pretty well set.
It's in the catalog, and you took it.
Okay.
The only advice you could get is, what can I get away with, because I didn't make this course.
I'd have had that problem, but there was no counseling as such that I know of.
How rigorous, how demanding were the courses in medicine compared with what you'd had before?
I never felt they were demanding in a way.
A lot of them I did not excel in.
But a lot of my problems was time.
And I teetered along just on the brink a good bit.
Were you paying your own way?
Oh, yes.
Okay.
$23 a month, and that took care of it.

I worked two years with the Agricultural Adjustment Administration in the county and saved money up and I gave my dad some and I talked him into buying a car and I gave him part of that to cover that and left.
And they'd send me $15, $20 occasionally.
About how many of your friends
had enough money that they didn't have to work?
About what percentage worked and didn't work?
What percent had a job here?
I would not want to be checked on that, but I would say that 30 or 40 percent of them had to work.
Yeah, I'm going to at least that.
All right, and so you all go year-round then to classes, and did any of many of your friends drop out and go volunteer, or did they stay pretty well?
You all stayed pretty well together.
There was an option there that was offered, and some of them did take that option to go on, and what happened was they had a...
Most of them took the commissions and then when they developed the Army Student Training Program, the STP, they went for a year and then they decided that we're not going to be needing these people.
That they all gave them the option of leaving that
and going on to do the service from there, or else just dropping out and continuing school.
And there were a few then that took that option, joining the Navy or what have you.
Then you reported for active duty when?
Well, after we resigned our commission and accepted this program, that was in June of 43.
You had already graduated?
No.
Oh.
We had a year to go.
June of 43, I was two years to go.
But in June of 43, this program started.
And then in 44, it ended.
And then we got out and continued school.
And we were all into a company, ASTP.
So you graduated when?
Was there a big ceremony, commencement?
You know, I don't even remember being there.
That's how significant it was.
So you don't remember where the family came or?
Oh, no, they didn't come.
Okay.
And then you reported for active duty?
